title: How to View Historical Imagery on Google Earth

steps.title: Open the Google Earth Pro app on your computer.
steps.content: Open the Google Earth Pro app on your computer. The only way to use Google Earth's historical imagery layer is to install the Google Earth Pro app on your PC or Mac. If you haven't installed it yet, you can get it from https://www.google.com/earth/about/versions . [1] X Research source Despite the "Pro" in the name, Google Earth Pro is 100% free.

steps.title: Search the location you want to view.
steps.content: Search the location you want to view. Type the location into the search box at the upper-left corner and click Search . Just like in Google Maps , Google Earth will bring you to the location you’ve entered. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Zoom in
steps.content: Zoom in if needed. At first, the area view may be too far up to be able to focus on the location. You can now use the vertical navigation bar on the right side of the map to zoom in for a closer look. Click the plus button at the top of the bar to zoom in. The map will immediately adjust as you zoom in. Continue to zoom in until you’re at the level of detail you want to see. Wait a few moments for the rendering to be completed for the location. Once it’s done, you will be able to see the location clearly and vividly, as if you’re right in front of it. You can again use the navigation buttons to move around the view of the location.

steps.title: Enable Historical Imagery.
steps.content: Enable Historical Imagery. Click the View menu on the header menu bar, then select Historical Imagery . A time-lapse bar will appear in the upper left corner. The bar has a horizontal scroll bar that you can adjust from the past to the present.

steps.title: View historical images of the location.
steps.content: View historical images of the location. Drag the scroll bar at the upper-left to the left to go back in time and view past images of the current location. Each time you adjust the scroll bar, the imagery for the location you’re viewing changes to show you how the location looked at the time you’re setting. A building you’re seeing now may not exist five or ten years ago. You will be amazed at what you can see by looking at the different images from the past. [3] X Research source
